title: Chemical spill outside Harrods leads to lockdown in Knightsbridge
text:
Police say the incident is not being treated as terror related (Picture: @SamYoung841; Triangle News)

Emergency services are dealing with a chemical spill outside a Harrods store in central London.

One person was treated at the scene and has been taken to hospital, according to the London Ambulance Service.

Brompton Road in Knightsbridge has been closed this afternoon, after police officers were called at 2.22pm.

London Fire Brigade says it was called to a chemical incident at a single-storey restaurant and 15 members of staff had left the building before it arrived.

Another 27 people were evacuated from a neighbouring block of flats.

The affluent area is home to high-end shops including Harrods.

A Metropolitan Police spokesman could not specify where the spillage had taken place.

A police officer works behind a cordon at a restaurant in the Knightsbridge area of central London after reports of a spillage of a possible noxious substance (Picture: AFP)

Police, ambulance and fire crews were called at 2:22pm today (Picture: Triangle News)

London Fire Brigade says it was called to a ‘chemical incident (Picture: @SamYoung841)

The force said: ‘Police were called at 2.22pm on Wednesday to reports of a possible noxious substance having been spilled at a commercial venue on Brompton Road.

‘Officers and London Ambulance Service are on scene. Cordons and closures are in place as a precaution, while the nature of the chemical is established.’

Police say that the incident is not being treated as terror-related.

Harrods and several other venues along Brompton Road in west London are thought to have been closed after the incident (Picture: iStock Editorial)

One witness was in the Freej Swaileh restaurant on Edgware Road when she was evacuated.

She said: ‘I could hear people yelling and apparently people used a toxic substance to clean the bathroom and they were not supposed to.

‘It exploded somehow and the smell went around the block and police said not to breath it in.

‘There was a strong plastic smell like burning plastic.’

Another witness said: ‘It smelt like a nuclear bomb had gone off.’
